section: list.h FreeRTOS/list.h Go to the documentation of this file.00001 /* 00002 * FreeRTOS Kernel V10.2.0 00003 * Copyright (C) 2019 Amazon.com, Inc. or its affiliates. All Rights Reserved. 00004 * 00005 * Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy of 00006 * this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal in 00007 * the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights to 00008 * use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell copies of 00009 * the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is furnished to do so, 00010 * subject to the following conditions: 00011 * 00012 * The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all 00013 * copies or substantial portions of the Software. 00014 * 00015 * THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED "AS IS", WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR 00016 * IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, FITNESS 00017 * FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND NONINFRINGEMENT. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE AUTHORS OR 00018 * COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER LIABILITY, WHETHER 00019 * IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM, OUT OF OR IN 00020 * CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN THE SOFTWARE. 00021 * 00022 * http://www.FreeRTOS.org 00023 * http://aws.amazon.com/freertos 00024 * 00025 * 1 tab == 4 spaces! 00026 */ 00027 00028 /* 00029 * This is the list implementation used by the scheduler. While it is tailored 00030 * heavily for the schedulers needs, it is also available for use by 00031 * application code. 00032 * 00033 * list_ts can only store pointers to list_item_ts. Each ListItem_t contains a 00034 * numeric value (xItemValue). Most of the time the lists are sorted in 00035 * descending item value order. 00036 * 00037 * Lists are created already containing one list item. The value of this 00038 * item is the maximum possible that can be stored, it is therefore always at 00039 * the end of the list and acts as a marker. The list member pxHead always 00040 * points to this marker - even though it is at the tail of the list. This 00041 * is because the tail contains a wrap back pointer to the true head of 00042 * the list. 00043 * 00044 * In addition to it's value, each list item contains a pointer to the next 00045 * item in the list (pxNext), a pointer to the list it is in (pxContainer) 00046 * and a pointer to back to the object that contains it. These later two 00047 * pointers are included for efficiency of list manipulation. There is 00048 * effectively a two way link between the object containing the list item and 00049 * the list item itself. 00050 * 00051 * 00052 * \page ListIntroduction List Implementation 00053 * \ingroup FreeRTOSIntro 00054 */ 00055 00056 #ifndef INC_FREERTOS_H 00057 #error FreeRTOS.h must be included before list.h 00058 #endif 00059 00060 #ifndef LIST_H 00061 #define LIST_H 00062 00063 /* 00064 * The list structure members are modified from within interrupts, and therefore 00065 * by rights should be declared volatile. However, they are only modified in a 00066 * functionally atomic way (within critical sections of with the scheduler 00067 * suspended) and are either passed by reference into a function or indexed via 00068 * a volatile variable. Therefore, in all use cases tested so far, the volatile 00069 * qualifier can be omitted in order to provide a moderate performance 00070 * improvement without adversely affecting functional behaviour. The assembly 00071 * instructions generated by the IAR, ARM and GCC compilers when the respective 00072 * compiler's options were set for maximum optimisation has been inspected and 00073 * deemed to be as intended. That said, as compiler technology advances, and 00074 * especially if aggressive cross module optimisation is used (a use case that 00075 * has not been exercised to any great extend) then it is feasible that the 00076 * volatile qualifier will be needed for correct optimisation. It is expected 00077 * that a compiler removing essential code because, without the volatile 00078 * qualifier on the list structure members and with aggressive cross module 00079 * optimisation, the compiler deemed the code unnecessary will result in 00080 * complete and obvious failure of the scheduler. If this is ever experienced 00081 * then the volatile qualifier can be inserted in the relevant places within the 00082 * list structures by simply defining configLIST_VOLATILE to volatile in 00083 * FreeRTOSConfig.h (as per the example at the bottom of this comment block). 00084 * If configLIST_VOLATILE is not defined then the preprocessor directives below 00085 * will simply #define configLIST_VOLATILE away completely. 00086 * 00087 * To use volatile list structure members then add the following line to 00088 * FreeRTOSConfig.h (without the quotes): 00089 * "#define configLIST_VOLATILE volatile" 00090 */ 00091 #ifndef configLIST_VOLATILE 00092 #define configLIST_VOLATILE 00093 #endif /* configSUPPORT_CROSS_MODULE_OPTIMISATION */ 00094 00095 #ifdef __cplusplus 00096 extern "C" { 00097 #endif 00098 00099 /* Macros that can be used to place known values within the list structures, 00100 then check that the known values do not get corrupted during the execution of 00101 the application. These may catch the list data structures being overwritten in 00102 memory. They will not catch data errors caused by incorrect configuration or 00103 use of FreeRTOS.*/ 00104 #if( configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES == 0 ) 00105 /* Define the macros to do nothing. */ 00106 #define listFIRST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00107 #define listSECOND_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00108 #define listFIRST_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00109 #define listSECOND_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00110 #define listSET_FIRST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE( pxItem ) 00111 #define listSET_SECOND_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE( pxItem ) 00112 #define listSET_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_1_VALUE( pxList ) 00113 #define listSET_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_2_VALUE( pxList ) 00114 #define listTEST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY( pxItem ) 00115 #define listTEST_LIST_INTEGRITY( pxList ) 00116 #else 00117 /* Define macros that add new members into the list structures. */ 00118 #define listFIRST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE TickType_t xListItemIntegrityValue1; 00119 #define listSECOND_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE TickType_t xListItemIntegrityValue2; 00120 #define listFIRST_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE TickType_t xListIntegrityValue1; 00121 #define listSECOND_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE TickType_t xListIntegrityValue2; 00122 00123 /* Define macros that set the new structure members to known values. */ 00124 #define listSET_FIRST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE( pxItem ) ( pxItem )->xListItemIntegrityValue1 = pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00125 #define listSET_SECOND_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE( pxItem ) ( pxItem )->xListItemIntegrityValue2 = pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00126 #define listSET_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_1_VALUE( pxList ) ( pxList )->xListIntegrityValue1 = pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00127 #define listSET_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_2_VALUE( pxList ) ( pxList )->xListIntegrityValue2 = pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE 00128 00129 /* Define macros that will assert if one of the structure members does not 00130 contain its expected value. */ 00131 #define listTEST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY( pxItem ) configASSERT( ( ( pxItem )->xListItemIntegrityValue1 == pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE ) && ( ( pxItem )->xListItemIntegrityValue2 == pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE ) ) 00132 #define listTEST_LIST_INTEGRITY( pxList ) configASSERT( ( ( pxList )->xListIntegrityValue1 == pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE ) && ( ( pxList )->xListIntegrityValue2 == pdINTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE ) ) 00133 #endif /* configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES */ 00134 00135 00136 /* 00137 * Definition of the only type of object that a list can contain. 00138 */ 00139 struct xLIST; 00140 struct xLIST_ITEM 00141 { 00142 listFIRST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE /*< Set to a known value if configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES is set to 1. */ 00143 configLIST_VOLATILE TickType_t xItemValue; /*< The value being listed. In most cases this is used to sort the list in descending order. */ 00144 struct xLIST_ITEM * configLIST_VOLATILE pxNext; /*< Pointer to the next ListItem_t in the list. */ 00145 struct xLIST_ITEM * configLIST_VOLATILE pxPrevious; /*< Pointer to the previous ListItem_t in the list. */ 00146 void * pvOwner; /*< Pointer to the object (normally a TCB) that contains the list item. There is therefore a two way link between the object containing the list item and the list item itself. */ 00147 struct xLIST * configLIST_VOLATILE pxContainer; /*< Pointer to the list in which this list item is placed (if any). */ 00148 listSECOND_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE /*< Set to a known value if configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES is set to 1. */ 00149 }; 00150 typedef struct xLIST_ITEM ListItem_t; /* For some reason lint wants this as two separate definitions. */ 00151 00152 struct xMINI_LIST_ITEM 00153 { 00154 listFIRST_LIST_ITEM_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE /*< Set to a known value if configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES is set to 1. */ 00155 configLIST_VOLATILE TickType_t xItemValue; 00156 struct xLIST_ITEM * configLIST_VOLATILE pxNext; 00157 struct xLIST_ITEM * configLIST_VOLATILE pxPrevious; 00158 }; 00159 typedef struct xMINI_LIST_ITEM MiniListItem_t; 00160 00161 /* 00162 * Definition of the type of queue used by the scheduler. 00163 */ 00164 typedef struct xLIST 00165 { 00166 listFIRST_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE /*< Set to a known value if configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES is set to 1. */ 00167 volatile UBaseType_t uxNumberOfItems; 00168 ListItem_t * configLIST_VOLATILE pxIndex; /*< Used to walk through the list. Points to the last item returned by a call to listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY (). */ 00169 MiniListItem_t xListEnd; /*< List item that contains the maximum possible item value meaning it is always at the end of the list and is therefore used as a marker. */ 00170 listSECOND_LIST_INTEGRITY_CHECK_VALUE /*< Set to a known value if configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES is set to 1. */ 00171 } List_t; 00172 00173 /* 00174 * Access macro to set the owner of a list item. The owner of a list item 00175 * is the object (usually a TCB) that contains the list item. 00176 * 00177 * \page listSET_LIST_ITEM_OWNER listSET_LIST_ITEM_OWNER 00178 * \ingroup LinkedList 00179 */ 00180 #define listSET_LIST_ITEM_OWNER( pxListItem, pxOwner ) ( ( pxListItem )->pvOwner = ( void * ) ( pxOwner ) ) 00181 00182 /* 00183 * Access macro to get the owner of a list item. The owner of a list item 00184 * is the object (usually a TCB) that contains the list item. 00185 * 00186 * \page listSET_LIST_ITEM_OWNER listSET_LIST_ITEM_OWNER 00187 * \ingroup LinkedList 00188 */ 00189 #define listGET_LIST_ITEM_OWNER( pxListItem ) ( ( pxListItem )->pvOwner ) 00190 00191 /* 00192 * Access macro to set the value of the list item. In most cases the value is 00193 * used to sort the list in descending order. 00194 * 00195 * \page listSET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE listSET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE 00196 * \ingroup LinkedList 00197 */ 00198 #define listSET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE( pxListItem, xValue ) ( ( pxListItem )->xItemValue = ( xValue ) ) 00199 00200 /* 00201 * Access macro to retrieve the value of the list item. The value can 00202 * represent anything - for example the priority of a task, or the time at 00203 * which a task should be unblocked. 00204 * 00205 * \page listGET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE listGET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE 00206 * \ingroup LinkedList 00207 */ 00208 #define listGET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE( pxListItem ) ( ( pxListItem )->xItemValue ) 00209 00210 /* 00211 * Access macro to retrieve the value of the list item at the head of a given 00212 * list. 00213 * 00214 * \page listGET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE listGET_LIST_ITEM_VALUE 00215 * \ingroup LinkedList 00216 */ 00217 #define listGET_ITEM_VALUE_OF_HEAD_ENTRY( pxList ) ( ( ( pxList )->xListEnd ).pxNext->xItemValue ) 00218 00219 /* 00220 * Return the list item at the head of the list. 00221 * 00222 * \page listGET_HEAD_ENTRY listGET_HEAD_ENTRY 00223 * \ingroup LinkedList 00224 */ 00225 #define listGET_HEAD_ENTRY( pxList ) ( ( ( pxList )->xListEnd ).pxNext ) 00226 00227 /* 00228 * Return the list item at the head of the list. 00229 * 00230 * \page listGET_NEXT listGET_NEXT 00231 * \ingroup LinkedList 00232 */ 00233 #define listGET_NEXT( pxListItem ) ( ( pxListItem )->pxNext ) 00234 00235 /* 00236 * Return the list item that marks the end of the list 00237 * 00238 * \page listGET_END_MARKER listGET_END_MARKER 00239 * \ingroup LinkedList 00240 */ 00241 #define listGET_END_MARKER( pxList ) ( ( ListItem_t const * ) ( &( ( pxList )->xListEnd ) ) ) 00242 00243 /* 00244 * Access macro to determine if a list contains any items. The macro will 00245 * only have the value true if the list is empty. 00246 * 00247 * \page listLIST_IS_EMPTY listLIST_IS_EMPTY 00248 * \ingroup LinkedList 00249 */ 00250 #define listLIST_IS_EMPTY( pxList ) ( ( ( pxList )->uxNumberOfItems == ( UBaseType_t ) 0 ) ? pdTRUE : pdFALSE ) 00251 00252 /* 00253 * Access macro to return the number of items in the list. 00254 */ 00255 #define listCURRENT_LIST_LENGTH( pxList ) ( ( pxList )->uxNumberOfItems ) 00256 00257 /* 00258 * Access function to obtain the owner of the next entry in a list. 00259 * 00260 * The list member pxIndex is used to walk through a list. Calling 00261 * listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY increments pxIndex to the next item in the list 00262 * and returns that entry's pxOwner parameter. Using multiple calls to this 00263 * function it is therefore possible to move through every item contained in 00264 * a list. 00265 * 00266 * The pxOwner parameter of a list item is a pointer to the object that owns 00267 * the list item. In the scheduler this is normally a task control block. 00268 * The pxOwner parameter effectively creates a two way link between the list 00269 * item and its owner. 00270 * 00271 * @param pxTCB pxTCB is set to the address of the owner of the next list item. 00272 * @param pxList The list from which the next item owner is to be returned. 00273 * 00274 * \page listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY 00275 * \ingroup LinkedList 00276 */ 00277 #define listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY( pxTCB, pxList ) \ 00278 { \ 00279 List_t * const pxConstList = ( pxList ); \ 00280 /* Increment the index to the next item and return the item, ensuring */ \ 00281 /* we don't return the marker used at the end of the list. */ \ 00282 ( pxConstList )->pxIndex = ( pxConstList )->pxIndex->pxNext; \ 00283 if( ( void * ) ( pxConstList )->pxIndex == ( void * ) &( ( pxConstList )->xListEnd ) ) \ 00284 { \ 00285 ( pxConstList )->pxIndex = ( pxConstList )->pxIndex->pxNext; \ 00286 } \ 00287 ( pxTCB ) = ( pxConstList )->pxIndex->pvOwner; \ 00288 } 00289 00290 00291 /* 00292 * Access function to obtain the owner of the first entry in a list. Lists 00293 * are normally sorted in ascending item value order. 00294 * 00295 * This function returns the pxOwner member of the first item in the list. 00296 * The pxOwner parameter of a list item is a pointer to the object that owns 00297 * the list item. In the scheduler this is normally a task control block. 00298 * The pxOwner parameter effectively creates a two way link between the list 00299 * item and its owner. 00300 * 00301 * @param pxList The list from which the owner of the head item is to be 00302 * returned. 00303 * 00304 * \page listGET_OWNER_OF_HEAD_ENTRY listGET_OWNER_OF_HEAD_ENTRY 00305 * \ingroup LinkedList 00306 */ 00307 #define listGET_OWNER_OF_HEAD_ENTRY( pxList ) ( (&( ( pxList )->xListEnd ))->pxNext->pvOwner ) 00308 00309 /* 00310 * Check to see if a list item is within a list. The list item maintains a 00311 * "container" pointer that points to the list it is in. All this macro does 00312 * is check to see if the container and the list match. 00313 * 00314 * @param pxList The list we want to know if the list item is within. 00315 * @param pxListItem The list item we want to know if is in the list. 00316 * @return pdTRUE if the list item is in the list, otherwise pdFALSE. 00317 */ 00318 #define listIS_CONTAINED_WITHIN( pxList, pxListItem ) ( ( ( pxListItem )->pxContainer == ( pxList ) ) ? ( pdTRUE ) : ( pdFALSE ) ) 00319 00320 /* 00321 * Return the list a list item is contained within (referenced from). 00322 * 00323 * @param pxListItem The list item being queried. 00324 * @return A pointer to the List_t object that references the pxListItem 00325 */ 00326 #define listLIST_ITEM_CONTAINER( pxListItem ) ( ( pxListItem )->pxContainer ) 00327 00328 /* 00329 * This provides a crude means of knowing if a list has been initialised, as 00330 * pxList->xListEnd.xItemValue is set to portMAX_DELAY by the vListInitialise() 00331 * function. 00332 */ 00333 #define listLIST_IS_INITIALISED( pxList ) ( ( pxList )->xListEnd.xItemValue == portMAX_DELAY ) 00334 00335 /* 00336 * Must be called before a list is used! This initialises all the members 00337 * of the list structure and inserts the xListEnd item into the list as a 00338 * marker to the back of the list. 00339 * 00340 * @param pxList Pointer to the list being initialised. 00341 * 00342 * \page vListInitialise vListInitialise 00343 * \ingroup LinkedList 00344 */ 00345 void vListInitialise( List_t * const pxList ) PRIVILEGED_FUNCTION; 00346 00347 /* 00348 * Must be called before a list item is used. This sets the list container to 00349 * null so the item does not think that it is already contained in a list. 00350 * 00351 * @param pxItem Pointer to the list item being initialised. 00352 * 00353 * \page vListInitialiseItem vListInitialiseItem 00354 * \ingroup LinkedList 00355 */ 00356 void vListInitialiseItem( ListItem_t * const pxItem ) PRIVILEGED_FUNCTION; 00357 00358 /* 00359 * Insert a list item into a list. The item will be inserted into the list in 00360 * a position determined by its item value (descending item value order). 00361 * 00362 * @param pxList The list into which the item is to be inserted. 00363 * 00364 * @param pxNewListItem The item that is to be placed in the list. 00365 * 00366 * \page vListInsert vListInsert 00367 * \ingroup LinkedList 00368 */ 00369 void vListInsert( List_t * const pxList, ListItem_t * const pxNewListItem ) PRIVILEGED_FUNCTION; 00370 00371 /* 00372 * Insert a list item into a list. The item will be inserted in a position 00373 * such that it will be the last item within the list returned by multiple 00374 * calls to listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY. 00375 * 00376 * The list member pxIndex is used to walk through a list. Calling 00377 * listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY increments pxIndex to the next item in the list. 00378 * Placing an item in a list using vListInsertEnd effectively places the item 00379 * in the list position pointed to by pxIndex. This means that every other 00380 * item within the list will be returned by listGET_OWNER_OF_NEXT_ENTRY before 00381 * the pxIndex parameter again points to the item being inserted. 00382 * 00383 * @param pxList The list into which the item is to be inserted. 00384 * 00385 * @param pxNewListItem The list item to be inserted into the list. 00386 * 00387 * \page vListInsertEnd vListInsertEnd 00388 * \ingroup LinkedList 00389 */ 00390 void vListInsertEnd( List_t * const pxList, ListItem_t * const pxNewListItem ) PRIVILEGED_FUNCTION; 00391 00392 /* 00393 * Remove an item from a list. The list item has a pointer to the list that 00394 * it is in, so only the list item need be passed into the function. 00395 * 00396 * @param uxListRemove The item to be removed. The item will remove itself from 00397 * the list pointed to by it's pxContainer parameter. 00398 * 00399 * @return The number of items that remain in the list after the list item has 00400 * been removed. 00401 * 00402 * \page uxListRemove uxListRemove 00403 * \ingroup LinkedList 00404 */ 00405 UBaseType_t uxListRemove( ListItem_t * const pxItemToRemove ) PRIVILEGED_FUNCTION; 00406 00407 #ifdef __cplusplus 00408 } 00409 #endif 00410 00411 #endif 00412
